Abstract 20 Quantitation of environmental pollutants has gained momentum due to its widespread 21 requirement in the fields of clinical research, occupational hygiene, public health, and societal 22 welfare. The use of functionalized fluorescent nanomaterials (FFNMs: e.g., metal nanoparticles, 23 semiconductor quantum dots, carbon dots, nanotubes, and nanocrystals) has opened a new 24 avenue for creating simple, selective, and non-invasive real-time analysis, as they can satisfy the 25 growing demand for rapid and cost-effective quantitation. Here, we discuss novel strategies for 26 the qualitative and quantitative analysis of a variety of organic and inorganic environmental 27 pollutants by detecting changes in photo-physical or optical properties (e.g., fluorescence, 28 absorbance, and color) of FFNMs used as probes. Particularly, we emphasize potential 29 approaches for the synthesis and characterization of FFNMs and their underlying interactions 30 with environmental pollutants. The simplification of design and enhancement of specificity 31 towards target analytes should be pursued further to upgrade their real-world applicability in 32 diverse fields. 33 34 Keywords: Synthesis; characterization techniques; functionalized fluorescent nanomaterials; 35 luminescence; quenching; detection; environmental pollutants 36 37 *Correspondence: 38 kkim61@hanyang.ac.kr, dr.akashdeep@csio.res.in, yongsikok@korea.ac.kr 39 1These authors are considered as co-first authors because they contributed equally to this work.40

1. Introduction 73 In recent years, nanomaterials (NMs) have attracted much attention due to their unique 74 electronic, optical, catalytic, and magnetic properties [1, 2]. As nanomaterials also offer great 75 stability, sensitivity, and size-dependent optical properties, they have been employed in diverse 76 applications including sensing, drug delivery systems, catalysis, gas/energy storage, adsorption, etc. 77 [3-8]. Due to such vast applicability, the scientific awareness of NM-based sensing applications has 78 been expanding rapidly, as evidenced by more than several thousands of research articles ( >5000) 79 published over the past decade. 80 Functionalization of NMs enhances their binding affinity towards specifically desired target 81 analytes. Such development is ideal for sensing harmful substances during various environmental 82 remediation processes. Additionally, functionalized fluorescent nanomaterials are advantageous for 83 a number of sensing applications due to their porous structure, large surface area, high loading 84 capacity, and specific interaction with analytes (such as lead, cadmium, copper, mercury, etc.). 85 Moreover, functionalization of NMs can considerably improve their stability in aqueous solution 86 by capping their surfaces with stabilizing agents, such as biomolecules, surfactants 87 (cationic/anionic), or organic molecules. In addition to protecting their luminescence properties, the 88 controlled surface capping of nanoparticles further endows them with target-specific sensing 89 capabilities. 90 Among the different NMs, silver (AgNPs) and gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) have been 91 extensively investigated for a variety of sensing applications. A broad absorption band in the 92 visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum is useful to characterize these NPs. Changes in color 93 or optical properties of AgNPs and AuNPs can be ascribed to their surface plasmon resonance 94 (SPR) absorption band [9]. The SPR property of NPs is strongly dependent on the size and shape of 95 the particle, the adsorbed species, the dielectric properties (or refractive index) of the medium, and 96 the inter-particle distances between the NPs [10]. The SPR absorption spectra of noble metal 97

nanoparticles are extremely sensitive to the local surrounding environment that changes after 98 interaction with pollutant molecules and surface attachment between them. 99 Contamination of toxic pollutants in various environmental media has become a great healthcare 100 concern due to their lethal, hazardous, and adverse effects on both the environment and human 101 beings. For example, Hg is ubiquitous in the air, water, and soil systems and is one of the most 102 hazardous toxic metals. Long-term exposure to Hg may cause various health problems, including 103 damage to the brain, nervous system, kidneys, and endocrine system [11, 12]. In aqueous 104 solutions, water-soluble Hg2+ species are converted into methyl mercury, which is subsequently 105 bioaccumulated through the food chain [13]. Methyl mercury is particularly dangerous for children 106 as it can cause several serious developmental delays [14]. Therefore, it is necessary to build simple, 107 inexpensive, and high performance methods to detect such hazardous compounds in the 108 environment with high selectivity. 109 In this paper, we provide a comprehensive review of the sensing applications of functionalized 110 fluorescent nanomaterials (FFNMs) for organic and inorganic environmental pollutants. Numerous 111 methods have been reported for the detection of organic and inorganic environmental pollutants as 112 shown in Table 1. Table 2 lists a number of studies carried out using different sensing techniques 113 for environmental analysis with functionalized fluorescent nanomaterials. Note that conventional 114 instrumental methods used for environmental analysis are diverse and include: spectrophotometry, 115 atomic absorption spectrometry, stripping voltammetry, inductively-coupled plasma atomic 116 emission spectrometry, high-performance liquid chromatography, ion selective electrode (ISE), 117 flame photometry, etc. Relative to these instrumental methods, nano-sensing techniques have 118 several advantages including simplicity, rapidity, sensitivity, high selectivity, ease of measurement, 119 use of inexpensive instruments, and time savings. In addition, the use of such approaches allows 120 direct non-invasive on-site measurements of target compounds. Although many attempts have been 121 made to describe the fundamental aspects of nano-sensing methods, there is still scant information 122

Functionalized fluorescent nanomaterials and the mechanism of their interaction with the 129 environmental pollutant 130 The size-tunable photophysical properties of functionalized nanomaterials (such as fluorescence 131 and absorbance), as shown in Fig. 1, are known to involve various inter-and intramolecular charge 132 transfer processes which are generally highly useful indices of fluorophore-analyte interactions. 133 Common mechanisms of fluorophore-analyte response are broad enough to include photoinduced 134 electron transfer (PET), metal to ligand charge transfer (MLCT), ligand to metal charge transfer 135 (LMCT), intramolecular charge transfer (ICT), fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET). 136 Changes in fluorescence during analysis may either be recorded as quenching or enhancement, 137 whereas alteration of the original color of nanomaterials may also occur due to aggregation. For 138 example, a gold nanocluster-based fluorescent sensor has been developed for the highly selective 139 and sensitive detection of cyanide ions in food, soil, and water [15]. The fluorescence quenching 140 takes place due to the formation of very stable Au (CN)2- complex through strong covalent 141 bonding. In addition, the hetero atom doped carbon quantum dots have also been developed for the 142 sensing of environmental pollutants. For example, N-doped carbon dots with their electron 143 acceptor/donor properties were applied for selective detection of TNT (electron acceptor) through 144 PET mechanism with the fluorescence quenching of N-CDs [16]. The transfer of electron (or 145 energy) from functionalized nanomaterials towards tested pollutants result into the changes in 146 fluorescence. Such change in absorbance intensity upon the addition of an analyte (or 147

Probe based on Nanoparticles and Nanoclusters 156 The use of functionalized noble magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) and quantum dots offers size-157 dependent optical and fluorimetric detection of environmental pollutants such as toxic heavy metal 158 ions, explosives, industrial effluents, pesticides, and mining waters [8, 16, 17]. For instance, poly 159 (ethylene amine) (PEI)-functionalized graphene quantum dots (PEI-GQD) synthesized from coffee 160 grounds [17] showed high selectivity for Fe3+ and Cu2+ among 16 metal ions. The high selectivity 161 was attributed to the strong binding affinity and fast chelating kinetics of Fe3+ and Cu2+ with GQDs 162 N functional groups. Recently, a time-saving and economic method was developed for 163 chemosensing of environmentally hazardous Cr(VI) ion , utilizing the fluorescent inner filter effect 164 (IFE) of carbon dot (CD) known to occur due to the absorption of excitation (primary IFE) or 165 emitted light (secondary IFE) by the absorbers in the detection system. This method offers 166 enhanced ion selectivity and sensitivity because the changes in the absorbance of the absorber due 167 to IFE effects translate into exponential changes in the fluorescence of the fluorophore unlike the 168 conventional fluorescence-based sensing strategies [19]. Interestingly, the surface state of 169 luminescent CD (L-CD) could be tuned to achieve desired photoluminescence (PL) characteristics. 170 Li et al. [20] achieved this by increasing the surface coverage of L-CD by amino groups (by 171 passivating other trapping states like C-O, C=O, and C=O-OH), resulting in excitation-independent 172

Probe encapsulated by biologically localized embedding 189 Nanoprobes encapsulated by biologically localized embedding have been employed preferably in 190 intracellular sensing or live-cell imaging. A fluorescent dye can be encapsulated within an inert 191 matrix to protect the dyes from interference (e.g. protein binding) in the sample; a nano-probe used 192 for live cell imaging is a good example of such an application [28]. Such probes generally offer 193 high spatiotemporal resolution and specificity towards the target molecule. Zhang et al. [29] 194 applied quinolone derivative-functionalized carbon dots for sensing and intracellular imaging of 195 Zn2+. Similarly, Fu and Cui [30] used thiosemicarbazide-functionalized carbon dots for sensing 196 Cu2+ and intracellular imaging. The carbon dots exhibited a highly specific recognition capability 197

Recently, metal NPs combined with fluorescent probe (such as rhodamine B) 200 have been used for the detection of different pesticides (e.g., organophosphorus and carbamates) in 201 water based on dual read out assay [31, 32]. 209 2.3. Probe based on the SERS phenomenon 210 It is well known that the interaction of functionalized noble metal NPs with analyte leads to a 211 change in the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) excitation energy which can then 212 enhance Raman light scattering, known as surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) [40, 41]. 213 SERS is highly effective technique for detecting analytes at considerably low concentrations. This 214 improved sensitivity is due to electromagnetic enhancement of the noble metal NPs through 215 compensation of the weak scattering cross section for the target compound. For example, 216 oligonucleotides attached to the NPs are compelling candidates for tagging unlabeled 217 complementary DNA and RNA targets to form the biosensor. DNA hybridized biosensors can then 218 be employed to identify pathogens in water by functionalizing the NPs with oligonucleotides that 219 are complementary to the pathogen’s DNA sequences as described in [42]. The unique localized 220 SPR of gold (AuNP) and silver (AgNP) NPs was utilized for the fabrication of colorimetric sensors 221

224 2.4. FRET-based probe for environmental analysis 225 Fluorescent metal NPs and quantum dot fluorophores are effective tools for environmental 226 analysis based on fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) [45, 46]. The FRET changes the 227 fluorescence of the fluorophore from an ‘ON’ state to an ‘OFF’ state. It occurs when the electronic 228 excitation energy of a donor fluorophore is transferred to a nearby acceptor molecule (analyte) 229 without exchanging light between the donor and the acceptor. Several factors affect the rate of 230 energy transfer, such as the distance between the donor and acceptor molecule, relative orientation 231 of the transition dipoles, and the amount of spectral overlap. FRET-based detection of DNA, metal 232 ions, and small organic molecules are described in detail in [45]. Recently, FRET-based detection 233 of bacterial pathogens like Bacillus anthracis and Pseudomonas aeruginosa has also been 234 recommended as a rapid diagnostic technique for the effective control of bacterial spread [47]. 235
236 2.5. Probe based on change in nanomaterial absorbance intensity 237 Another set of probes has been developed to sense environmental pollutants based on changes in 238 NP absorbance. Studies of the adsorption of proteins onto functionalized NPs by Boulos et al. [48] 239 and Pelaz et al. [49] are examples. The gold nanocluster-based fluorescent sensor, as cited 240 previously by [15], is another example describing the changes in absorbance intensity of 241 nanomaterials upon the addition of an analyte. In such cases, the change in absorbance of NPs upon 242 interaction with analytes becomes a useful pathway for the use of nanomaterials for environmental 243 analysis. In addition to nanosensing applications, NMs have been widely applied for the removal of 244 pollutants, such as the use of graphene-based nanomaterials for the adsorptive removal of metals 245 [2]. 246

247 3. Preparation of functionalized fluorescent nanomaterials 248 Functionalized noble metal NPs (e.g., gold and silver) have attracted much attention due to their 249 potential applications in nanoscience and nanotechnology. These nanomaterials have wide 250 applications in optical, magnetic, and electronic fields. These nanomaterials show a change in 251 photophysical properties upon interaction with analytes. One of the important characteristics 252 displayed by nanomaterials is surface plasmon resonance (SPR), which is highly dependent upon 253 NPs size [50]. The change in the local environment of FFNMs also results in the change to their 254 photophysical properties. The change in refractive index of the medium gives information about the 255 surface phenomenon. These changes can also be measured simply by fluorescence spectroscopy 256 and/or UV-visible absorption spectroscopy. A satisfying combination of fluorescence spectroscopy 257 with nanotechnology can yield an effective pathway for the detection and determination of 258 environmental samples. 259 Several preparation methods have been reported for FFNMs synthesis, including chemical 260 reduction, wet chemical, microwave-assisted, and spray pyrolysis [38, 39]. Among them, chemical 261 reduction is the simplest method (Fig. 2).Various other facile methods for synthesis of 262 nanocomposite gas sensors, including sol-gel, self-assembly, chemical, and electrical techniques, 263 have been developed [51]. Sanchez et al. [52] described the skills required for the synthesis of 264 hybrid nanocomposites with desired architecture and characteristics in line with market prospects. 265 On the other hand, the synthesis of functionalized metal NPs involves the surface capping of 266 nanoparticles with different stabilizing (capping) agents. NPs surface capping is very important for 267 sensing different analytes. For instance, the capping of AgNPs with CTAB (a surfactant) is 268 generally adopted for the detection of Hg2+ as well as D-Penicillamine (D-PA) in pharmaceutical 269 and water samples [53]. A novel hydrothermal method coupled with functionalization with poly 270 (ethylene imine) (PEI) was adopted for the synthesis of GQD from ground coffee beans [17]. 271

274 4. Characterization of functionalized fluorescent nanomaterials 275 FFNM probes, once designed, can be characterized by different instrumental techniques; some 276 important ones are described below. 277
278 4.1 Absorption and Fluorescence Spectroscopy 279 Absorption spectroscopy is the preferred characterization technique, through which the 280 absorption of radiation from a material is measured as a function of wavelength. When 281 nanomaterials are exposed to light, they absorb the light, causing electrons to move from their 282 ground state to an excited state. Subsequently, the electrons return to the ground state and release 283 the excess energy through both nonradioactive and radioactive pathways. It is one of the 284 nondestructive techniques to acquire information regarding the quantum yield of molecules and the 285 electron transitions in molecules. A maximum absorption of light by the material at a particular 286 wavelength can be represented by the λmax value. For instance, this technique was employed for the 287 characterization of poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG)-modified AuNPs [56]. 288
289 4.2 Dynamic Light Scattering Measurement 290 Particle size distribution of nanomaterials in a homogenous aqueous solution is obtained based 291 on the principle of Brownian motion of particles in an aqueous media by performing Dynamic 292 Light Scattering (DLS) experiments (Malvern Instruments Ltd., 2012). Hence, the average size of 293 nanomaterials is measured by hydrodynamic diameter, which includes particle size and solvation 294 molecule layers around the NPs. DLS methods were employed to measure particle size and size 295

298 4.3 Zeta Potential Measurements 299 Zeta (ζ) potential measurement is used to study the effectiveness of capping agents on the 300 surface of nanomaterials by characterizing the surface charge of the prepared NPs as well as their 301 stability [57]. Zeta potential value is either positive or negative depending upon the nature of the 302 capping agent. If a negative capping agent is stabilized on the surface of the nanomaterials, then the 303 zeta potential value will become negative, and vice versa. For example, zeta potential was explored 304 as a stability index for cholic acid functionalized polymeric NPs used as molecular biomaterials for 305 sustained and controlled drug delivery for the treatment of cervical cancer. 306
307 4.4 Surface Electron Microscopy (SEM) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) 308 For morphological characterization of nanomaterials, SEM photomicrography is a popular 309 technique. It requires an air-dried layer of nanoparticle suspended on solid substrates. The TEM 310 technique is also used to measure the exact particle size of nanomaterials. X-ray powder diffraction 311 is commonly used to assess the crystal structure of the synthesized NM. Newly synthesized 312 graphene quantum dots were characterized using atomic force microscopy (AFM), TEM, and XRD 313 techniques [15]. The average size of polymeric NPs determined by using SEM and TEM 314 techniques was less than half the size determined by the DLS method described above due to 315 shrinkage and possible collapse of the NP structure in dry conditions [50]. 316

5.2.4 Plausible mechanisms for changes in functionalized fluorescent nanomaterial photophysical 393 properties in analyte samples 394 It is well known that the changes in FFNMs photophysical properties are induced by their 395 interaction with sample analytes. In the case of a change in fluorescence, there should be a 396 possibility for complex formation between nanomaterials and analytes. Applications of FFNMs for detection of environmental pollutants 444 A broad array of nanomaterials are used in environmental pollutant analyses, including carbon 445 NMs, nanotubes, MNPs, and quantum dots [61]. Some of the applications were discussed in section 446 2. For instance, gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) and silver NPs (AgNPs) are widely used as a visual 447 probe in colorimetric detection of environmental pollutants [59]. Another example is a novel 448 colorimetric nanosensing-based method proposed by Chen et al. [9]. Nanomaterial-based strategies 449 for the analysis of trace amounts of mercury in drinking water was reviewed by Huber and Leopold 450 [62]. Figs. 5 and 6 show the functionalized nanomaterial–based sensing of ions. Liu et al. [63] and 451 Govindhan et al.
